Milrose games in New York City,
January 30. The relay race will be
one of the feature events of the
night. Syracuse has already signified their intention to send a team
to compete, and Georgetown is considering the trip. Other well-known
universities may enter, but the race
will be limited to a comparatively
small number of participants.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

We are proud of our Honor System, and we are proud of Hopkins. This is not meant, however, to be merely an euolgy. Its purpose is to inform members of the Freshman Class, who are taking
Hopkins examinations for the first time, that the Honor System is not
only a name but an established fact. We are certain that the Class
of 1927 will enter into the spirit of the "Code" and will be as proud
of it as we are.
We have always said that the time-honored greeting should
changed to "A Merry Christmas and Happy Mid-Years."

THE SWIMMERS
The swimming team, along with other minor sport organizations,
is laboring under enormous difficulties. The financial support given
by the athletic budget is insufficient; the team is practicing without
the services of a coach; lack of a pool at Homewood necessitates
irregular practice hours; the already limited squad is constantly
threatened by a malignant and unmerciful black list.
In spite of the obvious difficulties, the team opened its season
last week with a victory, defeating the Swarthmore mermen by a
decisive margin. A difficult schedule is still ahead of' the Hopkins
men but we are assured of a good showing.
The members of the swimming team are to be commended for
their efforts and for their spirit. An excelent way of showing our
appreciation is by supporting the home meets.
The News-Letter wishes to announce the election of Mr. Charles
G. Hutzler, '24, to the position of associate editor.

MAJOR RIELY GIVES LECTURE ON HYGIENE AND
SANITATION TO
R. O.T. C.
The Department of Military
Science has inaugurated a new
policy in the lectures being given
on Hygiene and Sanitation. Last
Monday, Major Charles Riely,
commander of the R. 0. T. C. at
the Medical School lectured on
these topics to the Sophomore and
Senior members of the unit. In
former years the officers of the
staff conducted classes on these
subjects, but the department has
decided that experts only should
teach them, so Major Riely was
secured to give the lectures.
Major Riely spoke on the general aspects of Military Hygiene
and Sanitation. This was followed
by a practical demonstration of
First Aid work by the Major and
two Medical Corps assistants.
Various splints, bandages and
other First Aid Devices were put
upon one of the men until he resembled a mummy. Demonstration of the Medical Corps field kit
Major
and stretchers followed.
Riely concluded with a short discourse on snake bites, at the request of Lieutenant Sherwood.
Major Riely will conduct a practical exercise today, at which students will be given an opportunity
to practice bandage work and the
methods of resuscitation. The lectures are supplemented by talks
on the same subjects by Lieutenant Sherwood.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

We are proud of our Honor System, and we are proud of Hopkins. This is not meant, however, to be merely an euolgy. Its purpose is to inform members of the Freshman Class, who are taking
Hopkins examinations for the first time, that the Honor System is not
only a name but an established fact. We are certain that the Class
of 1927 will enter into the spirit of the "Code" and will be as proud
of it as we are.

THE SWIMMERS
The swimming team, along with other minor sport organizations,
is laboring under enormous difficulties. The financial support given
by the athletic budget is insufficient; the team is practicing without
the services of a coach; lack of a pool at Homewood necessitates
irregular practice hours; the already limited squad is constantly
threatened by a malignant and unmerciful black list.
In spite of the obvious difficulties, the team opened its season
last week with a victory, defeating the Swarthmore mermen by a
decisive margin. A difficult schedule is still ahead of' the Hopkins
men but we are assured of a good showing.
The members of the swimming team are to be commended for
their efforts and for their spirit. An excelent way of showing our
appreciation is by supporting the home meets.
The News-Letter wishes to announce the election of Mr. Charles
G. Hutzler, '24, to the position of associate editor.

MAJOR RIELY GIVES LECTURE ON HYGIENE AND
SANITATION TO
R. O.T. C.
The Department of Military
Science has inaugurated a new
policy in the lectures being given
on Hygiene and Sanitation. Last
Monday, Major Charles Riely,
commander of the R. 0. T. C. at
the Medical School lectured on
these topics to the Sophomore and
Senior members of the unit. In
former years the officers of the
staff conducted classes on these
subjects, but the department has
decided that experts only should
teach them, so Major Riely was
secured to give the lectures.
Major Riely spoke on the general aspects of Military Hygiene
and Sanitation. This was followed
by a practical demonstration of
First Aid work by the Major and
two Medical Corps assistants.
Various splints, bandages and
other First Aid Devices were put
upon one of the men until he resembled a mummy. Demonstration of the Medical Corps field kit
Major
and stretchers followed.
Riely concluded with a short discourse on snake bites, at the request of Lieutenant Sherwood.
Major Riely will conduct a practical exercise today, at which students will be given an opportunity
to practice bandage work and the
methods of resuscitation. The lectures are supplemented by talks
on the same subjects by Lieutenant Sherwood.
